utterances: (singing) Here's your lesson In divinity.
No one does it Half as good as me.
If you're good at being bad Then it's no sweat By this time tomorrow You could be teacher's pet.

Cause you know I'm on a mission Of seduction I confess As the mood gets hotter We'll be wearing even less All the doors are bolted You might be here till dawn You can't stop the showgirl You can't stop the showgirl You can't stop the showgirl The showgirl Must go on.
When was the first time you caught Bette Midler's act?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org, and you can tell us your story on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the program, covering the R.
Kelly trial in Chicago.
But first, Better Midler joins us from our bureau in New York, and welcome to Talk of the Nation.
Thank you.
And in an otherwise rave review of your show in the New York Times, Charles Isherwood used a word I never thought would be associated with you - ""wholesome.
Oh, that's so sweet.
I didn't read the review.
I don't read reviews generally but that's actually very nice.
After all this time.
I guess everyone caught up to me finally.
And when was the first time you appeared in Las Vegas?
Gee, I was - I think the first time I ever went to Las Vegas was in the early '70s, maybe even the late '60s, like '69 or '70.
I worked for Johnny Carson.
I opened his show for him.
And at the time, well, you were a lot younger.
Did people get the act?
You were younger, too.
You know what?
Not exactly, but he was - he stuck with me.
He was a big defender.
He really enjoyed me and it was a fun time.
Vegas was a lot different then, too.
It was very, very different.
It was definitely - it wasn't as big, and it wasn't as - I mean, really it's quite vast now.
There's the strip, of course, but then there's so much.
It's 30 miles in every direction, and in those days it wasn't like that.
It was a relatively small town and it was - you could know it.
You could get to know it pretty well.
There were a few high spots and then the rest was a desert.
And what was the room you played back in '70, '71, '72?
It was the Sahara.
I'm not sure what the name of the room was.
It might've been - it could have been something like the Congo Room or something like that.
I'm not really sure, but it was - we played the Sahara, and I really enjoyed it.
Whenever I pass it, I want to run in and see if that showroom is the same.
We went to see the Follies Bergere at the Tropicana and that is really old-school Vegas, and I could recommend that show to anyone who's interested in that style of entertainment.
And compare the room you played back 30 years ago to the room you're playing now.
Well, it's - the new room is a room that Caesar's Palace built for Celine Dion, and it's a state-of-the-art theater.
It's a fantastic house.
It seats 4,500 people very comfortably and it has - there isn't a bad seat in the whole house.
The sound system is state-of-the-art, the lighting system is state-of-the-art.
She had a whole humidification system built under the stage.
The dressing rooms are fantastic.
It really is extraordinary.
No one who's ever - I have friends who've been in, you know, rock 'n' roll their whole lives and no one has ever seen a dressing room like this, ever.
So it's really extraordinary that the room I played with Johnny Carson in, it was old school.
It had bankettes.
It was sort of a semi-circle and it had bankettes and tiers and it was much, much smaller, and it was cozier.
It was very, very cozy, and you felt, you know, immediately as though you were at home.
Very sweet room.
We took the show out to Las Vegas a couple of years ago and I had the chance to see not that theater but the one that was built, I think, for Cirque de Soleil.
Unbelievable.
Well, which one?
There are seven or eight Cirques there.
I know, this was the water one.
That is the greatest show I ever saw in my entire life.
In my whole - I've never, I never thought that I would live to see a show like that.
It was extraordinary!
It was like a dream.

I was very affected by it and in fact, I brought my whole crew with me and at the end people were sobbing and standing up and screaming because as people who put on shows, the idea that you had those resources and that you would do something so imaginative with what they had given you, it just blew us away.
The theaters are amazing.
Just the state-of-the-art with the computer-guided - well, everything is great.
Anyway.
Yes, it is.
It really is extraordinary, and the effects that some of the Cirque shows, especially, manage to make are so - they've never been seen before.

Now that was a big challenge for us because I'm a human being and I, you know, I'm not an aerialist, I'm not, I don't - I'm not a contortionist and I didn't want to have those kind of - I mean, I love those people and I admire them, but that's really not what I do.
What I do is - I do a lot of things.
I sing, I dance and I tell terrible jokes, and I try to do something that's very human scale.
And that was a big challenge because all the Cirque shows are gigantic and they're - they don't have a personality at the center of them.
(Singing) How I miss the social intercourse so very, now I have to have it with the guy I'm married.
So now I'd rather watch your...
(Soundbite of audience applause)
I'm stumped on that one.
So Craig Childs, there was a lot of really fascinating information in your book about how people actually go about taking artifacts and then even smuggling artifacts.
I mean, can you talk a little bit about how people get this stuff out of the ground and onto the black market?
Well, around where I live, especially over in Utah and the Four Corners area, the artifacts are often so close to the surface that people helicopter in.
And there have been cases where the helicopter has lowered its tail rotor toward the ground and actually blown off the surface where they can actually see objects starting to appear.
Oh my gosh.
And so people are coming in by helicopter or by airplane.

I was out there getting buzzed once by an airplane coming down on the Navajo Reservation that was going over and over a site that was right behind me, that I had just found for the first time, a large, buried, ceremonial chamber.
And as they were flying over, I was figuring, you know, I bet they're selling this site.
I bet there's somebody in the airplane going, yeah, that looks good.
I think we can get $10,000 out of that.
So how do legal sales affect the black market?
Well, the more artifacts that are sold, the more artifacts are needed, and artifacts then get laundered.
They lose their context until they can join a collection and appear to be legal.
So in many ways, there's no such thing as a black market because eventually, these artifacts do rise up, and even ones that are illicitly acquired, they look like they're legal.
They look like they're completely legit.
So then give us an example of an artifact that's - I guess maybe made it to a museum, where that journey might have been a little bit dubious.
Well, if you follow the Euphronios vase that went to the Met...
And what did this look like?
A beautiful, large, ceramic, almost like a little bathtub that you would mix water and wine in.
You'd go into the Met and there it was in its own display case, just beautiful paintings of warriors and gods all around it, just one of the finest Greek vessels ever found.
And it was sold with paperwork that said, you know, this thing is legal.
But a lot of people questioned it, and after a while, it was finally figured out, through raids and photographs and notebooks that it was indeed smuggled.
What is the difference between archeology and grave robbing?
Well, archaeology as a science is holding on to the information.
So you're digging up an object, and you have the context around it.
You know, did this pot come from a kitchen site, a living room, a burial?
And you can date objects around it, and you keep this context.
And so there's that balance between what we want, the general public, in terms of learning about history, our own or of other cultures, and I guess disturbing these worlds that are out there.
Oh, yeah.

It's a tough balance because I've worked on quite a few archaeological excavations where you're down in a trench digging with a trowel and wondering, what on earth am I doing, digging through some dead person's belongings?
It definitely is eerie, and I know many archeologists who feel the same way.
Even though a lot of information comes out and we know so much more about the past, there's still this sense of violation that you're digging into somebody else's life.
Your book talks a lot about figures who, once they're arrested or indicted related to wrongdoing in this world, commit suicide or, like, these fights and feuds between folks in this industry.
And it kind of makes you think of pirates or something.
I mean, there is this element of, I guess danger, for lack of a better word.
Yeah.
In a strange way, it's a very violently charged atmosphere where, you know, during the writing of this book, several people that I was following died by suicide or one woman died in her jail cell.
Others went to prison.
It's got a certain kind of edge to it that I kind of trace back to the emotional edge.
There's such an attachment to what is the right and wrong thing to do with these objects and what is legal, what is illegal.
And it really rises to the surface where I know some archeologists who want pot hunters dead, and I know pot hunters who want archeologists dead.
There are some bad rivalries going on here.
What does this mean for how you think about what is right when it comes to antiquities?
Well, seeing things on the ground, seeing things where they are, I've come to believe that artifacts need to stay in their place.

And that's after having gone through museum collections and seeing just the vast amounts of material that we've gathered already and going through private collections and just realizing how much we have swept up from the ground.
